DialogueOption.Text: I have a question about the ship.

Dialogue.Page: Yeah, sure. What's up?

DialogueOption.Text: What happened to my Little Scout's recall?
What happens if the ship gets too hot?
How does the thrust modulator work?
How do the autopilot controls work?
Why does the ship have a signal?
How does the radio work?
How do I use the tether hooks?
Why did you put a flag in my ship? It seems kind of useless.
Can my ship warp to anywhere other than Timber Hearth?
The retro rockets don't work.
Why is the cockpit covered in rust?
Is it just me or does the ship keep changing every time I wake up?
Nevermind.

Dialogue.Page: I was going to integrate the new Nomai technology into it, but I figured it would be too heavy for you to carry around out there.

DialogueOption.Text: You thought one extra pound would be too heavy?
How am I supposed to get my scout back?!

Dialogue.Page: Look, weight adds up when you decide to bring five cans of jumbo marshmallows.
You can still use your scout without that fancy technology. You just need to go pick it up by hand.
Calm down! Is picking your scout up by hand really that big of a deal?
I hope not. You're gonna be doing a lot of stuff by hand out there.
And don't worry, you can still recall it with the ship. Just make sure that you get the scout from the top of the ship after.

DialogueOption.Text: Why's that?
Okay.

Dialogue.Page: You share your scout with the ship. When you fire your ship's scout launcher, it moves the scout to the top of the ship.
But when you call it back to the ship's launcher, your handheld launcher can't get it back, so it gets stuck on top of the ship.

DialogueOption.Text: That's annoying.
Couldn't you just fix that by adding the Nomai technology to the scout?

Dialogue.Page: You'll get used to it. I don't feel like trying to put the Nomai technology back in the scout.
Yeah, but I don't feel like trying to put the Nomai technology back in the scout.
If you think it's that important to have, you can try integrating it yourself.
Oh, that? I used the wrong metal coating for the glass. Could have easily been avoided, now that I think about it.
It should be fine, as long as the rust isn't covering the entire cockpit.

DialogueOption.Text: ...It is.
That ship is definitely a death-trap.
If you say so...

Dialogue.Page: It is? Stars above, that coating oxidized fast.
Look, Gossan's got an eye missing, and they could still fly a ship as well as any other Hearthian! You should have no problem piloting it with all four eyes and a cockpit coated in rust.
Just... try to think transparent thoughts.
At least it's a death trap that can fly! When was the last time you got to go in a death trap that could fly?
You keep away from the ship's hull if that happens. You don't want a superheated sheet of metal coming into contact with you.
There's also a chance the fuel tanks might explode, but that only happens if the ship gets really hot.
Don't worry, you'll be fine! Just don't leave the ship somewhere warm.

DialogueOption.Text: What about if it gets super cold?
I guess I'd better stay away from the Hourglass Twins, then.

Dialogue.Page: The engines don't do well in cold temperatures. They would lock up here in the village if it weren't for the reactor's heat.
I would stay out of cold areas, if I were you. You might have trouble leaving if you stay too long.
I'm sure the heat is tolerable on those planets. It's a good thing they aren't any closer to the sun, though.

DialogueOption.Text: What if the ship gets super cold?

Dialogue.Page: Again? ...You're sure?

DialogueOption.Text: Completely broken.
Were they ever working in the first place?

Dialogue.Page: Stars above, it's like those rockets have a mind of their own. You saw them working yesterday, right?

DialogueOption.Text: I wouldn't call what I saw "working".
Yeah. Can you fix them again?

Dialogue.Page: Okay fine, they weren't exactly working. But they were at least firing, which is more than I can say for them right now.
Of course they were! They're just a little stubborn, that's all.
Give me 30 minutes, then I'll come and look at them.

DialogueOption.Text: But the Sun's going to explode in 30 minutes!
Can you look at them now? I don't have time to wait for you.
Sounds good.

Dialogue.Page: What? I'm no astrophysicist, but I know it takes a lot longer than 30 minutes for the Sun to explode.
Let me enjoy these marshmallows, I'll come look at it soon.
Woah, why the sudden rush? It's not like the ship is going anywhere.
Well... that's not true. I never checked if the autopilot could turn itself on.
Let me enjoy my marshmallows, then if the ship is still there I'll come fix it.
Had a weird dream, did you? The ship is the same as it's always been.

DialogueOption.Text: Yeah, must have just been a dream.
No, I'm serious. The ship never used to look like that.

Dialogue.Page: Glad you're finally coming to your senses. Now hurry up and go launch the ship!
You okay, hatchling? Did you inhale some of those fumes by accident?

DialogueOption.Text: Yeah, must have.
I'm telling you, that ship keeps changing and it's creeping me out.

Dialogue.Page: Well, be more careful next time. You're lucky I'm not having Hornfels ground you for medical reasons right now.
You're the one who's creeping me out, because I have no idea what you're talking about.
I'm radioing Hornfels. You're definitely not flying that ship today.

DialogueOption.Text: Wait, what? You're grounding me!?
With the way the ship is acting, I wouldn't have flown it anyways.

Dialogue.Page: Of course I am! You're talking nonsense!
Now go get some rest. You can try launching again next week.
Stars above, what is wrong with you today? I've never seen pilots get this nervous before launching, and I've seen some pretty nervous pilots.
Go get some rest, hatchling. You can try launching again next week.
It lets you modulate your thrust! What did you think it did?
You can press those orange buttons to set a limit on your thruster output and go slower.

DialogueOption.Text: What if I want to go faster?
Alright, thanks.

Dialogue.Page: That's where the overdrive comes in. It sends an explosion through the engines and launches you forward.
You'd think an explosion like that would make the thrusters worse, but they actually work better for a little while. Isn't that weird?
You can activate the overdrive with the two buttons next to the thrust modulator. Just make sure you disable the safeties first.

DialogueOption.Text: Is this safe..?
Got it, thanks.

Dialogue.Page: Of course not! In what world would sending an explosion through the engines be safe?
It causes the reactor to overheat, but it's not like it'll blow up the ship or anything. Probably.
Now stop worrying the ship and go launch it already!
No problem. Now let me get back to my marshmallows.
There's always going to be two buttons that are turned on. That's telling you what'll be activated when you try matching velocity or using autopilot.
The two buttons on the left control what your autopilot does, and the other three buttons control what your match velocity does.
Do you need a reminder on what any of the buttons actually do?

DialogueOption.Text: The approach autopilot button.
The orbital outopilot button.
The input hold button.
The match velocity button.
The match position button.
No, thanks.

Dialogue.Page: That one's your regular old autopilot. Lock onto something and activate it, and it'll fly you to your destination.
I didn't give it an obstacle avoidance function, so make sure there's nothing in the way of your destination.
Activating that will put your ship into a stable orbit around whatever you're targeting. It'll try to stay at whatever distance you activate it at.

That one lets you record your inputs. Just start matching velocity, give the ship an input, and then stop matching velocity. It'll keep holding that until you turn off the button or give it a different input.
That one does what it says. It'll match the velocity of whatever you have targeted.
That one acts kind of like match velocity, except it'll keep your ship in the same position that you activated it at. If it gets moved from its spot, it'll fly right back.
Alright, good luck out there! And try not to trust the autopilot with your life, it'll let you down.
Oh, that's just a byproduct of the ship's signalscope.
Seemed like a waste of a signal though, so I made some modifications to that signalscope of yours.

DialogueOption.Text: What sort of modifications..?
I never said you could do that!

Dialogue.Page: Nothing necessarily dangerous. There's a small chance it causes a short circuit, but it's nothing to worry about.
Then maybe you shouldn't leave your signalscope laying around next time! You were practically asking for me to make improvements to it.
All I did was adjust your signalscope to transmit signals. If you aim it at the ship, you should be able to send it commands.

DialogueOption.Text: Woah, that's cool.
Does it make the ship explode or something?

Dialogue.Page: Yeah, it's one of my better ideas. Just make sure you don't send the wrong command.
Uh... among other things, yeah.

DialogueOption.Text: Awesome.
Why would anyone want to blow up their ship!?

Dialogue.Page: It's not as useful as the other commands, like ejecting the cockpit. I think you'll find more use out of those.
Hey, you never know what situations you'll find yourself in out there. Maybe your ship got stuck in a tunnel you really need to use.
And in case it wasn't clear, that command is only for emergencies. No blowing up the ship for fun.
Anyway, I've got a fire to enjoy and you've got a ship to launch. Good luck out there!
Once you attach a hook to something, you can tether yourself to it, and it'll stop you from moving too far away. You can adjust the length of the tether too if you want.
If you tether yourself to a hook and manage to reach a second one, you can connect the two hooks together. It's pretty straightforward, isn't it?

DialogueOption.Text: What do I use them for?
Yep. Thanks.

Dialogue.Page: Whatever you want! Personally, I would use them to hold the ship together better. It's a miracle it hasn't fallen apart already.
Anytime, hatchling.
That old thing? Yeah, it doesn't have much use to it. It sure brings back memories, though.
A long time ago, before the space program was even a thing, Feldspar was always talking about those other planets up there. Said they would fly to each and every one of them.
So the other hatchlings and I made a white flag for Feldspar. That way when they finally made it to another planet, they could set it up there for everyone to see.

When the space program was founded, we put the Outer Wilds Ventures sticker on that flag, so it looks a little different. But that's still the same flag Feldspar used when they landed on the Attlerock for the first time.
Plan was to put one on every planet, but I guess that never happened, with Feldspar going missing and all that.
Anyway, we had a few more that we made in storage, so I thought, you know, since you're going into space, maybe you could bring one with you. Just to put down somewhere out there.

DialogueOption.Text: Yeah. I can do that.
Maybe I'll pay Feldspar a visit and bring them a flag.

Dialogue.Page: Heh, maybe you can finish the job and set one up on each planet.
If you do that, take some photos to show me when you get back, will you?
Wish I could visit Feldspar too, hatchling, but until someone finds them, they won't be getting their flag.
You know what, though? If you somehow find Feldspar out there, be sure to come back here and tell me.
What, you think I flew around the Solar System and set up warp receivers on each planet? No, it can't warp to other planets. Not normally, at least.
Since the ship log uses Nomai parts in the computer, it might be possible for it to connect to other Nomaian technology and warp to them.
If you find something out there that can warp objects back to it, try marking it in the ship log or locking on to it. That should be enough to coax them into interfacing.
That old thing? It works like any radio does. You turn those little knobs to adjust the frequency, and if you find a good frequency it'll start playing music.
These days you'll find a whole lot of nothing with it. Most of the old signals have been taken down, and the newer radios and signalscopes work on a different set of frequencies.

DialogueOption.Text: Do you know any good frequencies?
Alright, thanks.

Dialogue.Page: I put some of the classics on the wall next to the radio, but everyone knows those. Personally, I would tune in to 5511.

DialogueOption.Text: Got it.
